body: **Submitting author:** @tothuhien (Thu-Hien To) **Repository:** https://github.com/UofABioinformaticsHub/strandCheckR **Version:** v1.1.2 **Editor:** @mgymrek **Reviewer:** @rmflight **Archive:** 10.5281/zenodo.2555032 ## Status [![status](http://joss.theoj.org/papers/526e5d062277f5e46154b00f7e6e1587/status.svg)](http://joss.theoj.org/papers/526e5d062277f5e46154b00f7e6e1587) Status badge code: ``` HTML: Markdown: [![status](http://joss.theoj.org/papers/526e5d062277f5e46154b00f7e6e1587/status.svg)](http://joss.theoj.org/papers/526e5d062277f5e46154b00f7e6e1587) ``` **Reviewers and authors**: Please avoid lengthy details of difficulties in the review thread. Instead, please create a new issue in the target repository and link to those issues (especially acceptance-blockers) in the review thread below. (For completists: if the target issue tracker is also on GitHub, linking the review thread in the issue or vice versa will create corresponding breadcrumb trails in the link target.) ## Reviewer instructions & questions @rmflight, please carry out your review in this issue by updating the checklist below. If you cannot edit the checklist please: 1. Make sure you're logged in to your GitHub account 2. Be sure to accept the invite at this URL: https://github.com/openjournals/joss-reviews/invitations The reviewer guidelines are available here: https://joss.theoj.org/about#reviewer_guidelines. Any questions/concerns please let @mgymrek know. ✨ **Please try and complete your review in the next two weeks** ✨ ## Review checklist for @rmflight ### Conflict of interest - [x] As the reviewer I confirm that I have read the [JOSS conflict of interest policy](https://github.com/openjournals/joss/blob/master/COI.md) and that there are no conflicts of interest for me to review this work. ### Code of Conduct - [x] I confirm that I read and will adhere to the [JOSS code of conduct](https://joss.theoj.org/about#code_of_conduct). ### General checks - [x] **Repository:** Is the source code for this software available at the repository url? - [x] **License:** Does the repository contain a plain-text LICENSE file with the contents of an [OSI approved](https://opensource.org/licenses/alphabetical) software license? - No [license](https://github.com/UofABioinformaticsHub/strandCheckR/issues/2) file. It is licensed according to CRAN and Bioconductor standards, but not commonly accepted OSS project standards. - This was resolved by [this commit](https://github.com/UofABioinformaticsHub/strandCheckR/commit/1340208624961bf0a5ee142cb539b3d5099c08a9) - [x] **Version:** v1.1.2 - [x] **Authorship:** Has the submitting author (@tothuhien) made major contributions to the software? Does the full list of paper authors seem appropriate and complete? - Yes, based on the git contributions, it seems the authors list is appropriate and complete. ### Functionality - [x] **Installation:** Does installation proceed as outlined in the documentation? - Yes, installation proceeds without problems. As noted in [this issue](https://github.com/UofABioinformaticsHub/strandCheckR/issues/6), I do suggest removing the list of required packages from the README, as Bioconductor installs the dependencies without difficulty. - [x] **Functionality:** Have the functional claims of the software been confirmed? - Yes, I have confirmed that I can run the code provided in the vignette, and that it behaves as outlined in the vignette and paper. - [x] **Performance:** If there are any performance claims of the software, have they been confirmed? (If there are no claims, please check off this item.) - The paper has a performance claim that is not verified. See [this issue](https://github.com/UofABioinformaticsHub/strandCheckR/issues/8). ### Documentation - [x] **A statement of need:** Do the authors clearly state what problems the software is designed to solve and who the target audience is? - This is stated in the paper, and in the package documentation, but not in the README. Copying over the statement from the DESCRIPTION should be sufficient. See [this issue](https://github.com/UofABioinformaticsHub/strandCheckR/issues/4). - [x] **Installation instructions:** Is there a clearly-stated list of dependencies? Ideally these should be handled with an automated package management solution. - Dependencies are handled just fine by the Bioconductor installer. - [x] **Example usage:** Do the authors include examples of how to use the software (ideally to solve real-world analysis problems). - There is no example of usage in the README, but the included vignette does provide a fully worked example. I think including the commands listed in the package level documentation into the README would be sufficient. See [this issue](https://github.com/UofABioinformaticsHub/strandCheckR/issues/5). - [x] **Functionality documentation:** Is the core functionality of the software documented to a satisfactory level (e.g., API method documentation)? - The core functionality is documented, in that there are descriptions for each function and their arguments. - However, some of the documentation lacks examples, and there are places where I believe the documentation could be improved, as outlined in [this pull request](https://github.com/UofABioinformaticsHub/strandCheckR/pull/3) and [this issue](https://github.com/UofABioinformaticsHub/strandCheckR/issues/9). - [x] **Automated tests:** Are there automated tests or manual steps described so that the function of the software can be verified? - There are automated tests. - [x] **Community guidelines:** Are there clear guidelines for third parties wishing to 1) Contribute to the software 2) Report issues or problems with the software 3) Seek support - No Contributing file or description provided. See [this issue](https://github.com/UofABioinformaticsHub/strandCheckR/issues/7) ### Software paper - [x] **Authors:** Does the `paper.md` file include a list of authors with their affiliations? - [x] **A statement of need:** Do the authors clearly state what problems the software is designed to solve and who the target audience is? - [x] **References:** Do all archival references that should have a DOI list one (e.g., papers, datasets, software)?

Does the full list of paper authors seem appropriate and complete? ### Functionality - [x] **Installation:** Does installation proceed as outlined in the documentation? - [x] **Functionality:** Have the functional claims of the software been confirmed? - [x] **Performance:** If there are any performance claims of the software, have they been confirmed? (If there are no claims, please check off this item.) ### Documentation - [x] **A statement of need:** Do the authors clearly state what problems the software is designed to solve and who the target audience is? - [x] **Installation instructions:** Is there a clearly-stated list of dependencies? Ideally these should be handled with an automated package management solution. - [x] **Example usage:** Do the authors include examples of how to use the software (ideally to solve real-world analysis problems). - [x] **Functionality documentation:** Is the core functionality of the software documented to a satisfactory level (e.g., API method documentation)? - [x] **Automated tests:** Are there automated tests or manual steps described so that the function of the software can be verified? - [x] **Community guidelines:** Are there clear guidelines for third parties wishing to 1) Contribute to the software 2) Report issues or problems with the software 3) Seek support ### Software paper - [x] **Authors:** Does the `paper.md` file include a list of authors with their affiliations? - [x] **A statement of need:** Do the authors clearly state what problems the software is designed to solve and who the target audience is? - [x] **References:** Do all archival references that should have a DOI list one (e.g., papers, datasets, software)?
